results.title: All the right stuff
results.creator_credit: Connie Littlefield, Mike Mahoney and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Join Brendan as he spends $200 of his disposable birthday cash on clothes, music and entertainment. He is just one of a large group that is an image marketers dream; young, impressionable, earning money from a low paying service job with money to burn. Whilst working his way in and out of well known brand name shops, he, as well as other teenagers, shop owners and adults, discuss the impact of advertising on them, how it influences their sense of being and consumer purchasing. They also share their thoughts for their future.

results.title: All that jazz starring Kenny Ball and his Jazzmen
results.brief_description: Documentary film featuring Kenny Ball and his Jazzmen performing live on stage interspersed with personal anecdotes by Kenny Ball about his life on the road as a jazz musician. The music is great, from dixieland to gospel, and includes the memorable “Midnight in Moscow” along with “When the Saints go marching in”, “We shall not be moved” and many other jazz favourites. No credits available.

results.title: All that heaven allows [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Douglas Sirk, Ross Hunter and Universal International Pictures
results.brief_description: A respected middle-aged New England widow (Jane Wyman) with two grown children becomes the victim of smalltown gossip when she rejects socially acceptable alternatives for the love of her gardener, a much younger man (Rock Hudson). Sirk uncovers something of the paradox of middle America in the fifties - gleaming surfaces masking a crisis in values - by using the elements of the woman’s melodrama from within to expose the confining complacency and emotional aridity of small town middle-class life. Cast also includes Agnes Moorhood, Virginia Grey, Gloria Talbot and William Reynolds.

results.title: All my own bush
results.brief_description: A Secondary School student takes a movie camera to the bushland around Monbulk and is suddenly aware of man’s intrusion into the bush. Suitable for mid-upper Primary School.

results.title: All men are liars
results.creator_credit: Gerard Lee, John Maynard and Arena Films
results.brief_description: In an attempt to reunite his family, which has fallen apart over a hocked piano, sensitive 17 year old Mick O’Brien joins the all girl “Total Fire Band” to earn some extra cash. He falls in love with the lead singer Angela whos been jilted by one too many lying men. She’s hot for Mick too, but not because hes cute and talented, but being a woman he’s sure to be honest! Great performances from Toni Pearen and especially John Jarrat as the has-been Elvis impersonator adds to the hilarity of this left-of-centre comedy.

results.title: All the presidents men
results.creator_credit: Alan Pakula, Walter Coblenz, Warner Bros Pictures and Wildwood Enterprises
results.brief_description: This is an understated thriller which remains close to Woodward and Bernstein’s account of the uncovering of the Watergate trail of corruption right to the President’s door. Together with Klute (1971) and The Parallax View (1974) it forms what has been called Pakula’s ‘paranoia trilogy’: film noir for the seventies. This film updates the investigative drama in pseudo-documentary style which had been a significant phase of film noir in the forties. The labyrinth in 1973 is the communication network which has to be commanded and manipulated for the investigator-reporters to uncover the enigmas facing them, the voice of Deep Throat in the darkness of subterranean carparks notwithstanding. Cast includes Dustin Hoffman, Robert Redford, Jack Warden, Martin Balsam and Jason Robards. Based on the book by Carl Bernstein and Bob Woodward.

results.title: All in together
results.creator_credit: Mike Boland, Tarni James, Canaus Films and Film Victoria
results.brief_description: A warm and inspiring documentary which explores the attitudes and relationships between disabled and abled children through the liberating experience of a week long campout. Both mentally and physically disabled children discover a sense of self and achievement. Parents of disabled children also present their views.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mike Boland, Tarni James, Canaus Films and Film Victoria

results.title: All our lives
results.creator_credit: National Film Board of Canada and Sky Works Charitable Foundation
results.brief_description: All of Our Lives examines the reasons why many women face economic hardship and emotional isolation in old age. It is a film about past dreams and, for the most part, unexpected realities. Elderly women from a variety of backgrounds and circumstances recall their girlhood ideals, and contrast them with the experiences of their actual adult lives. The film challenges audiences to re-evaluate the undervalued and often “invisible” world of child-rearing and work in the home.

results.title: All in the same boat
results.creator_credit: Debby Kingsland, Robin Hughes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: One of three films as part of the National Drug Education Program, this is a documentary on drug dependence in the daily lives of ordinary people. The central character of this film is a suburban housewife, Barbara, in her early twenties. She finds the dreary unchanging routine of her daily life very difficult to accept and the drug Valium has become part of Barbara’s daily life. Photography by Dean Semler. (See also “Thirst” T/C 012683 and “Hassles” T/C 012851)

results.title: All I desire [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Douglas Sirk, Ross Hunter and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Seasoned stage actress, Naomi Murdoch (Barbara Stanwyck), receives a letter from her long lost daughter, Lily (Lori Nelson), inviting her to come and see her star in a local production. After years in the big city, Naomi impulsively decides to return to the small-town where she once lived. Despite the good intentions, Naomi’s return disrupts the small-town life, provoking a myriad of reactions from each family member - from delight to despair - and re-igniting an old flame with a shady character. “All I desire” turns on the divide between city/small-town, female independence/domesticity, recklessness/conformity, with each character embodying either side. The only one torn between the two is Naomi who yearns deeply for the love of her husband and children. However, right at the last minute, the past returns to threaten this promise of happiness and domestic bliss once and for all. “All I desire” is classic melodrama: emotion and desire fills every scene. Douglas Sirk, with producer Ross Hunter, continues in this film his reputation as the master of ‘50s melodrama: expressive use of camera, lighting and performance; total devotion to pangs of the heart and soul, gender and desire, performance and identity and the limits of social convention. At the centre of “All I desire”, however, is Stanwyck’s performance, which shifts from hardened working girl to graceful lady to soft, dear-hearted mother with natural ease. It is a performance that knocks a punch into this film’s underlying theme: the bittersweet notion that in life we often learn things the hard way.
